Outfits like Alchemy Partners and Permira are among the European buyout firms that have been forced by the financial crisis to adjust management teams and funds. abstract: SciClone Pharmaceuticals said Friday it had discontinued a study of its experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after a recommendation by a safety review committee.
snippet: SciClone Pharmaceuticals said Friday it had discontinued a study of its experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after a recommendation by a safety review committee.
lead_paragraph: SciClone Pharmaceuticals said Friday it had discontinued a study of its experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after a recommendation by a safety review committee. The drug, known as RP101, is a nucleoside analog that was being tested for patients with late-stage cancer of the pancreas, the company said. The decision to stop the study was based on a review of data by a safety monitoring group overseeing the trial, the company said. SciClone, based in Foster City, Calif., markets Zadaxin, a treatment for hepatitis B, hepatitis C and certain cancers. The RP101 study was in the second of three phases generally required by regulators before they will approve a drug. The company did not specify what the safety panel found.

headline.main: Drug Maker Halts Test of Pancreatic Cancer Drug
headline.print_headline: Drug Maker Halts Test of Pancreatic Cancer Drug

abstract: EnteroMedics said on Friday that its implantable weight-loss device failed in a study.
snippet: EnteroMedics said on Friday that its implantable weight-loss device failed in a study.
lead_paragraph: EnteroMedics said on Friday that its implantable weight-loss device failed in a study. The trial, called Empower, was designed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Maestro system, which uses neuroblocking technology to stem hunger. Preliminary data did not show more weight loss with the device than without it, the chief executive, Mark Knudson, said on a conference call. Mr. Knudson said the trial found no immediate safety concerns with the device. The company plans to review the data to determine how to continue in obesity treatments and whether to explore the possibility of other indications, he said. Stock in EnteroMedics, which is based in St. Paul, fell $3.50, or 78 percent, to 97.84 cents a share.

headline.main: An Obesity Treatment Fails in a Trial
headline.print_headline: An Obesity Treatment Fails in a Trial

abstract: What would describe an adorable child of an edgy filmmaker?
snippet: What would describe an adorable child of an edgy filmmaker?
lead_paragraph: Crossword puzzles do their entertaining in polite society and even though constructors like Lynn Lempel are always trying to push the envelope, crosswords are expected to exercise a certain amount of decorum. Certainly at this publication you will never see a clue like “Intestinal opening.” It doesn’t pass what is commonly called the Breakfast Test, a reference to the amount of scatological humor you can stomach before either spitting coffee all over your french toast, or writing a Letter to the Editor using the phrases “shocked and appalled” and “this clue stinks.” And yet here it is at 10 Down. The question mark at the end saves the day. It means we’re not required to take the clue literally. I’m perhaps confessing too much when I say I love the clue. Are you with me? Or does it bum you out?

headline.main: Initial Offerings

abstract: Are concerns about increased costs to business well founded? Or has a tipping point been reached?
snippet: Are concerns about increased costs to business well founded? Or has a tipping point been reached?
lead_paragraph: A wave of defections from the United States Chamber of Commerce continued last week when Exelon, one of the country’s largest utilities, announced its departure. John W. Rowe, the utility’s chief executive, said Exelon was leaving because of the chamber’s “stridency against carbon legislation.” The chamber has recently opposed an Environmental Protection Agency proposal to use the Clear Air Act to set limits on greenhouse gases. In addition, chamber officials have been quoted calling for a “Scopes monkey trial” about the science of climate change. The chamber, which recently clarified its position on climate policy, says it is concerned that measures intended to address global warming will raise costs for business.

headline.main: Is the Chamber of Commerce Right About Climate Change?

abstract: The Dutch Finance Ministry and Deutsche Bank are still in talks to meet an EU competition remedy that would allow a merger between state-owned ABN Amro and Fortis Bank Nederland, the ministry said Monday.
snippet: The Dutch Finance Ministry and Deutsche Bank are still in talks to meet an EU competition remedy that would allow a merger between state-owned ABN Amro and Fortis Bank Nederland, the ministry said Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch Finance Ministry and Deutsche Bank are still in talks to meet an EU competition remedy that would allow a merger between state-owned ABN Amro and Fortis Bank Nederland, the ministry said Monday. The European Commission gave the Dutch government, which nationalised Dutch ABN AMRO and Fortis operations last year, an extension late Friday night to close an asset sale deal because of an ‘‘imminent’’ transaction with a ‘‘large international bank.” The ABN AMRO assets to be sold are the same ones Deutsche Bank was in talks to buy until Sept. 17, when talks between the ministry and bank broke off. When asked if the Dutch Finance Ministry was also in talks with French bank BNP Paribas about a possible deal to meet the EU remedy, a ministry spokeswoman said: ‘‘We have made a proposal (to the European Commission) with possibilities. That’s all I can say for now.’’

headline.main: Dutch in Talks With Deutsche on Bank Sale

lead_paragraph: Matt Ginsberg is back with another creative and unusual puzzle. If you haven’t tried this Tuesday crossword, I have a special quiz just for you. Name a common English word that has the sequence MPG somewhere in the middle. No, I’m not even going to tell you how many letters. Got it? How about ADQ? KSG? The toughest might be ZKR. If you’re struggling, you’d be right to suspect compound words are useful to consider. The ZKR answer derives from another language, but it also appears in English dictionaries. Two more: SPB and NKC.

abstract: Employers who have a large number of uninsured low wage workers may be motivated to drop coverage for the lower-ranking employees who do have coverage.
snippet: Employers who have a large number of uninsured low wage workers may be motivated to drop coverage for the lower-ranking employees who do have coverage.
lead_paragraph: One interesting comment on last week’s post about proposed employer mandates for health care coverage came from someone who called herself “AnnS.” AnnS seemed to know a lot about health insurance decision-making, and she led us through the calculation that one low-wage firm, apparently a regional convenience store chain, would make if faced with an employer mandate. AnnS is pessimistic. “Employers like this — who have a large number of uninsured low-wage workers — WILL NOT provide those workers with coverage and WILL BE motivated to drop coverage for the lower-ranking employees who do have coverage,” she wrote.

headline.main: Counterpoint: How a Mandate Could Cost Employees Their Company Insurance

abstract: The interesting thing about entrepreneurship is that you can encounter stress either because you are busy and growing and making money — or because you are not.
snippet: The interesting thing about entrepreneurship is that you can encounter stress either because you are busy and growing and making money — or because you are not.
lead_paragraph: Even though there are signs that the economy may be starting to turn around, this has been and continues to be a stressful year for most business owners. I often think stress should be spelled $tre$$. I cannot think of many jobs that pay a good amount of money that don’t also offer a good amount of stress. The interesting thing about entrepreneurship is that you can encounter stress either because you are busy and growing and making money — or because you are not. After many years of ups and downs, I have some tips on how to deal with stress in productive ways:

headline.main: Six Ways to Deal With Small-Business Stress

abstract: The Speaker of the House discusses the advantages of a value-added tax.
snippet: The Speaker of the House discusses the advantages of a value-added tax.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, sounded quite open to the idea of a value-added tax during her recent appearance on Charlie Rose. (James Pethokoukis of Reuters has the details.) As I briefly explained in my column today, a value-added tax — or VAT — is essentially a national sales tax. It has the advantage of taxing consumption rather than income, which should encourage savings. Savings, in turn, leads to corporate investment, and investment leads to economic growth. As taxes go, the VAT has much to recommend it.

headline.main: Pelosi, the VAT and Club Wagner

abstract: An interview with Sharon Brown, the founder of Environmental and Occupational Safety Services, about the challenges of being a government contractor.
snippet: An interview with Sharon Brown, the founder of Environmental and Occupational Safety Services, about the challenges of being a government contractor.
lead_paragraph: In 1995, Sharon Brown and her husband, Daryck, founded Environmental and Occupational Safety Services at their kitchen table. The company, which retrains workers in the fields of environmental engineering and cleanup, started to grow by winning contracts from the state of New Jersey and later branched out to do work for the federal government as well. It now has offices in Red Bank, N.J., and in Washington, and has fluctuated between five and 15 employees depending on work flow. The company’s revenue topped $500,000 in 2008 and could go as high as $700,000 in 2009. It just won a $500,000 contract from the U.S. Air force to redesign safety equipment..

headline.main: Building a Company on Government Contracts

abstract: One of the first things many people notice after upgrading to Apple’s iTunes 9 is that the program’s browser pane has moved to a vertical list along the left side of the iTunes window.
snippet: One of the first things many people notice after upgrading to Apple’s iTunes 9 is that the program’s browser pane has moved to a vertical list along the left side of the iTunes window.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things many people notice after upgrading to Apple’s iTunes 9 is that the program’s browser pane, which lists artists, albums and genre, has moved to a vertical list along the left side of the iTunes window. If you prefer the old browser position (which sat along the top of the iTunes window with side-by-side panes that showed the music library’s artists, albums and, optionally, genre), you can change it back. Go to the View menu in iTunes, select Column Browser and choose On Top instead of On Left. (If the browser isn’t showing, choose Show Column Browser from the View menu first.)

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Positioning the Browser Pane in iTunes 9

lead_paragraph: I’ve been blogging here for almost four months now, and it occurs to me that in an attempt to bring some reality to business ownership, I may have written more about the stress of entrepreneurship and the dark side of entrepreneurship than about the joy and glee of the adventure. Wildly. Now that it is huge and moving into all sorts of businesses that go beyond pure search, journalists and competitors question its every motive. And Google is determined not to get Microsoft-ed, where a company with a huge footprint in technology and culture ends up being seen as a monopolist and a threat, as opposed to an innovator.

abstract: At a meeting in China, AP and News. Corp. cock the gun in the content wars.
snippet: At a meeting in China, AP and News. Corp. cock the gun in the content wars.
lead_paragraph: Decoder (the boldface is ours) read those gunshots across the bow in an A.P. story linked on Romenesko, natch.  (The New York Times is a client of The Associated Press and we’re just using snippets, so we’re not picking anybody’s pocket here.) The pair was speaking in Beijing to representatives from 170 media outlets from 80 countries at a meeting to investigate whether the Web is a platform full of promise or, perhaps, a gallows for professionally gathered content. The rhetoric is rather breathtaking, although getting content back into a (paid) bottle is going to be an onerous task. Google is obviously the gigantic aggregating elephant in the room, but when Eric Schmidt was asked about The A.P. on Wednesday in a meeting with reporters, he pointed out that Google already had an agreement with the wire service, albeit one that expired this year, and said that as a matter of practice, the company did not discuss renewal arrangements.But speaking with Danny Sullivan of Search Engine Land last week in a far-ranging discussion about the production and dissemination of content, Mr. Schmidt said that Google was often indicted for offenses that really derived from the very existence of the Web.

headline.main: Two News Execs Cock the Gun in Content Fight

abstract: The quest for a regulator that will keep financial consumers from being taken to the cleaners by their bank or their mortgage broker or their credit card issuer.
snippet: The quest for a regulator that will keep financial consumers from being taken to the cleaners by their bank or their mortgage broker or their credit card issuer.
lead_paragraph: … from the president, that is, on Friday afternoon. Breaking away from his health care blitz, he defended the importance of the proposed new agency, which has suddenly begun to look a little vulnerable, as the banking lobby and the Chamber of Commerce have begun a nonstop assault before the mark-up in the House Financial Services Committee this coming week. It’s about time. Inexplicably, the White House has allowed the business lobbies to define the new agency — a bunch of power-hungry bureaucrats who want to impose onerous new regulations, etc., etc. — which, in turn, has put Congressional Democrats on the defensive. The bill has already been watered down somewhat to make it more palatable to the community bankers who have so much sway in every Congressional district. It’s time now to move the thing along.

lead_paragraph: Federal regulators will look into complaints by AT&T that the Google free messaging and calling service, Google Voice, blocks calls to rural communities where local phone companies charge high connection fees. The Federal Communications Commission on Friday wrote to Google requesting information about its Voice service, which lets people sign up for one number that can route incoming calls to a cell, office or home phone. AT&T has complained that Google Voice blocks calls to phone numbers in some rural communities to reduce the access charges it must pay.

abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Bear Stearns, Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse Group agreed to pay $100 million to settle a lawsuit over their roles in the bankruptcy of a Philadelphia mortgage lender, a lawyer said.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase, Bear Stearns, Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse Group agreed to pay $100 million to settle a lawsuit over their roles in the bankruptcy of a Philadelphia mortgage lender, a lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, Bear Stearns, Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse Group agreed to pay $100 million to settle a lawsuit over their roles in the bankruptcy of a Philadelphia mortgage lender, a lawyer said. The trustee for the defunct American Business Financial Services sued the banks in state court in Philadelphia, claiming they had helped keep the company going by letting it overstate the value of its assets. The banks agreed to the settlement on Oct. 7, Steven Coren, a lawyer for George Miller, the trustee, said Thursday. JPMorgan and Bear Stearns agreed to pay $55 million, Mr. Coren said.

headline.main: Banks Said to Settle Suit Over Mortgage Lender

lead_paragraph: The investment manager BlackRock said on Friday that the Bank of America executives Sallie L. Krawcheck and Mark D. Linsz had joined its board. Ms. Krawcheck, 44, is president of global wealth and investment management for Bank of America, and former chief financial officer for Citigroup. She left the board of the computer maker Dell last week, citing the need to focus on her duties with Bank of America. Mr. Linsz, 45, is corporate treasurer for Bank of America.

abstract: A year after Washington rescued banks too big to fail, the ones deemed too small to save are approaching a grim milestone: the 100th bank failure of 2009. In what is now a ritual, the F.D.I.C. has swooped down on a handful of troubled lenders almost every Friday, seizing 98 since January.

lead_paragraph: A year after Washington rescued the banks considered too big to fail, the ones deemed too small to save are approaching a grim milestone: the 100th bank failure of 2009. lead_paragraph: David Rockefeller Sr. ordered a new boat last year, a $3 million 55-foot powerboat. Mr. Rockefeller, now 94 years old, may not have needed a new boat. It was, after all, the sixth he has bought from Hinckley Yachts in Southwest Harbor, Me. But Hinckley Yachts and its workers certainly needed the order — and providing them with work was part of Mr. Rockefeller’s motivation, his spokesman said.

lead_paragraph: After falling for two years, global oil demand is expected to grow in 2010, once the economy kicks back to life. abstract: Nan Robertson: Reporter
snippet: Nan Robertson: Reporter
lead_paragraph: A collective tip of the hat from Decoder to Nan Robertson, a former New York Times reporter who died on Tuesday. Ms. Robertson’s coverage of workplace parity at The Times helped prepare the newspaper for a future where women lead, write and report in every corner of its coverage. Ms. Robertson wrote frankly about her alcoholism, reminding that booze has no respect for class or gender. And when toxic shock put her in a coma and robbed her of the tips of her fingers, she used what remained of her hands to type her way to a Pulitzer Prize in describing her ordeal.

headline.main: Nan Robertson: Reporter

lead_paragraph: Update | 5:37 p.m. The TLC channel on Friday sued Jon Gosselin, a star of its show “Jon & Kate Plus Eight,” for allegedly breaching his contract by giving unauthorized interviews. The suit was filed in the circuit court in Montgomery County, Md. Jon and Kate Gosselin, who appear alongside their eight children on the reality show, had signed contracts with the channel that stipulated how and when they could grant interviews and make public appearances. After the couple filed for divorce, TLC last month said it would retool the show as “Kate Plus Eight,” diminishing Mr. Gosselin’s role.

headline.main: TLC Files Suit Against Jon Gosselin for Contract Violation

abstract: Recollections from a child of the Depression whose father, a lawyer, documented the struggles of those years.
snippet: Recollections from a child of the Depression whose father, a lawyer, documented the struggles of those years.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Roth went to work in his father’s law practice, in Youngstown, Ohio, in the mid-1950s, his first assignment was to read the diary his father had kept during the Great Depression. Benjamin Roth wanted his son to understand the trauma most of his clients had been through, so that he could give them legal advice that would take into account their Depression experience. Daniel Roth had long known that his father had kept a diary, but he was startled by it nonetheless — by its literary power, and also by the amount of sheer effort his father had put in trying simply to understand the events he was living through.

headline.main: The Depression Diary

abstract: The Dutch financial services company agreed to sell its United States reinsurance business to the Reinsurance Group of America for an undisclosed amount.
snippet: The Dutch financial services company agreed to sell its United States reinsurance business to the Reinsurance Group of America for an undisclosed amount.
lead_paragraph: ING Groep, the Dutch financial services company, agreed to sell its United States reinsurance business to the Reinsurance Group of America for an undisclosed amount in a move to increase its capital. The disposal will have a “limited positive impact” on ING’s 2010 results, while the transaction will probably free up about 100 million euros ($149 million) in capital, ING said. The transaction is structured as a reinsurance agreement, ING said Friday. ING, which received a lifeline worth 10 billion euros from the Netherlands last year, plans to raise as much as 8 billion euros and free up 4 billion euros of capital selling assets to repay the Dutch state. The bank and insurer agreed on Thursday to sell its Asian private banking assets for $1.46 billion to the Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation of Singapore.

headline.main: Ing Sells Its U.S. Reinsurance Unit

abstract: Goldman Sachs, The New York Times’s Frank Rich writes, is this century’s octopus, the nickname given to John D. Rockefeller for creating capitalism’s most ruthless monster.
snippet: Goldman Sachs, The New York Times’s Frank Rich writes, is this century’s octopus, the nickname given to John D. Rockefeller for creating capitalism’s most ruthless monster.
lead_paragraph: At the dawn of the progressive era early in the last century, muckrakers attacked the first billionaire, John D. Rockefeller, for creating capitalism’s most ruthless monster. “The Octopus” was their nickname for Standard Oil, the trust that controlled nearly 90 percent of American oil. But even in that primordial phase of the industrial era, Mr. Rockefeller was mindful of his public image and eager to counter it, The New York Times’s Frank Rich writes. “His great brainstorm,” writes his biographer, Ron Chernow, “was undoubtedly his decision to dispense shiny souvenir dimes to adults and nickels to children as he moved about.” Who could hate an octopus tossing glittering coins?

headline.main: Goldman, Can Spare You a Dime?

Better earnings by the toymaker Hasbro, coming on the heels of a stronger-than-expected retail sales report from the government, helped to strengthen hopes that people were again spending money on nonessentials as the economy healed. Intel has said that computer sales are rebounding and sales at Apple, the maker of iPods and iPhones, topped expectations when the company reported a profit after markets closed on Monday.

abstract: As any sportswriter on a beat can tell you, making game stories interesting day in and day out can be a brutal challenge. But now, a story can be bolted together without human intervention.
snippet: As any sportswriter on a beat can tell you, making game stories interesting day in and day out can be a brutal challenge. But now, a story can be bolted together without human intervention.
lead_paragraph: Sportswriting has long played host to some of the most glorious, along with the most cliché-ridden, exercises in journalism. As anybody on a sports beat can tell you, making game stories interesting day in and day out can be a brutal challenge, but for those with lesser ambitions, it can be something that you do in your sleep. Now some kids at the Intelligent Information Laboratory at Northwestern University are suggesting that an average game day story can be bolted together without human intervention.

headline.main: The Robots Are Coming! Oh, They’re Here.

abstract: A new report finds that the second quarter of 2009 had the largest decline in state tax collections since at least 1963.
snippet: A new report finds that the second quarter of 2009 had the largest decline in state tax collections since at least 1963.
lead_paragraph: The chart above is taken from the Rockefeller Institute of Government’s latest report on state finances, based on Census Bureau data. Overall state tax collections in the second quarter of 2009 declined by 16.6 percent (17.8 percent when adjusted for inflation) from the same quarter of the previous year.

headline.main: State Tax Revenues Falling Off a Cliff

abstract: Gartner foresees a modest recovery in technology spending next year led by consumers, communications services and government stimulus programs.
snippet: Gartner foresees a modest recovery in technology spending next year led by consumers, communications services and government stimulus programs.
lead_paragraph: The qualified good news from Gartner’s new forecast of technology spending isn’t really surprising. Analysts there see a recovery in worldwide spending on information technology in 2010, after a 5.2 percent decline this year, the worst global falloff ever.

headline.main: Consumers and Communications to Lead Tech Recovery

abstract: A report from the inspector-general at the Department of Energy lays out a number of flaws in the program, including the fact that nearly all compact fluorescent bulbs can acquire the Energy Star label.
snippet: A report from the inspector-general at the Department of Energy lays out a number of flaws in the program, including the fact that nearly all compact fluorescent bulbs can acquire the Energy Star label.
lead_paragraph: The Energy Star program, run by the government, is supposed to bestow a seal of approval on consumer products that use less energy than competing models. But it has a number of flaws, as laid out in a new report released by the inspector general of the Energy Department, which administers the program with the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline.main: Report on Energy Star Lays Out Flaws, Highlighting Compact Fluorescents

abstract: The Deal Professor examines how a recent decision in the Delaware Court of Chancery in the case of In Re John Q. Hammons Hotels, has the potential for bringing about a revival of the management buyout.
snippet: The Deal Professor examines how a recent decision in the Delaware Court of Chancery in the case of In Re John Q. Hammons Hotels, has the potential for bringing about a revival of the management buyout.
lead_paragraph: One of the relics of 1980s deal-making was the large management buyout — such as the bid for RJR Nabisco — which has since seen its demise. But a recent decision in the Delaware Court of Chancery in the case of In Re John Q. Hammons Hotels, has the potential for bringing about a revival of this deal form. For good measure, the decision may also affect the course of the purchase of Affiliated Computer Services by Xerox.

headline.main: Decision May Help Revive Management Buyouts

abstract: The New York Times says it will trim 100 newsroom jobs by the end of the year, a reduction of about 8 percent.
snippet: The New York Times says it will trim 100 newsroom jobs by the end of the year, a reduction of about 8 percent.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times plans to eliminate 100 newsroom jobs — about 8 percent of the total — by year’s end, offering buyouts to union and non-union employees, and resorting to layoffs if it cannot get enough people to leave voluntarily, the paper announced on Monday.The program mirrors one carried out in the spring of 2008, when the paper erased 100 positions in its newsroom, though other jobs were created, so the net reduction was smaller. That round of cuts included some layoffs of journalists — about 15 to 20, though The Times would not disclose the actual figure — which was the first time in memory that had happened.

headline.main: Times Says It Will Cut 100 Newsroom Jobs

abstract: In a new study, two environmental organizations argue that plans to build a hydroelectric dam on the Zambezi River could result in South Africa’s having to choose between light or water.
snippet: In a new study, two environmental organizations argue that plans to build a hydroelectric dam on the Zambezi River could result in South Africa’s having to choose between light or water.
lead_paragraph: In a study released in the Mozambican capital of Maputo on Monday, two environmental organizations — International Rivers and Justica Ambiental — say plans to build the Mphanda Nkuwa hydroelectric dam on the Zambezi, a river spanning six countries, could result in South Africa’s having to choose between light and water.

headline.main: Debate Over Dams on Africa’s Zambezi River

lead_paragraph: Hedge funds were finally able to stem the tide of investor redemptions last quarter, recording a small, but symbolic, $1.1 billion net gain in assets under management — the first such gain in a year, according to Hedge Fund Research. The move follows 12 months in which investors pulled an astounding $330 billion out of the hedge fund market, which at it zenith last year had around $1.8 trillion in assets.

headline.main: Hedge Funds Post First Gain in Assets in Year

abstract: In this excerpt from a new book, Lehman’s chairman reaches out in several directions to find relief for his sinking firm.

lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2008, two months before Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the firm's chairman, was continuing his desperate efforts to find a lifeline. They had begun in March, shortly after the demise of Bear Stearns, when Mr. Fuld called the legendary investor Warren E. Buffett seeking a capital infusion, to no avail. Lehman had raised money elsewhere, but that didn't help for long, and its condition again was worsening.

headline.main: The Race to Save Lehman Brothers

We’re not alone. Last week, commenting on one of The Agenda’s analyses, a reader, Peter Lee, alerted us to another critique. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal-leaning group focusing on income inequality, takes issue with the Baucus bill’s mandate on other grounds.

abstract: Where California requires lengthy environmental assessments for clean-energy projects, Texas rushes ahead with wind farms.
snippet: Where California requires lengthy environmental assessments for clean-energy projects, Texas rushes ahead with wind farms.
lead_paragraph: As I wrote in Sunday’s Week in Review section, California and Texas have both emerged as leaders in renewable energy – but in completely different ways. Texans despise regulations, an attitude that has helped wind farms to flourish; California, by contrast, requires hefty environmental assessments for large projects – which helps explain why rooftop solar panels and energy efficiency have done so well (they do not need painstaking reviews).

headline.main: Two States, Two Paths to Clean Energy

snippet: Despite a strong quarter in which it attracted investors, BlackRock, the giant money manager, has not been totally successful in winning back all the cash that left its riskier products last year and went into low-yielding cash equivalents perceiv...
lead_paragraph: BlackRock’s chief executive, Laurence D. Fink, had a lot to celebrate on Tuesday as his big investment firm reported third-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts’ estimates. The firm’s hedge funds have nearly erased the losses posted during the financial crisis last year and are at or near their high-water marks. Meanwhile, BlackRock’s other alternative investment strategies were able to attract billions of dollars in new capital for its higher-yielding and riskier asset classes.

abstract: The familiar complaint “banks aren’t lending money” is silly. It is definitely harder to borrow these days, but the banks are lending to some people. The question is, who are those people?
snippet: The familiar complaint “banks aren’t lending money” is silly. It is definitely harder to borrow these days, but the banks are lending to some people. The question is, who are those people?
lead_paragraph: If you read my post last week about banking, you know I’m not a big defender of banks, especially big banks. Like a lot of people who commented on that post, I have a hard time understanding why so little of the bailout money the big banks got from our government seems to trickle down to small business owners. We are doing business in a new world. There are new rules.

headline.main: The Secret Language of Bankers

abstract: Gmail warns if you have accidentally included a contact with a similar name — instead of the name of the person you usually include in a regular list of e-mail recipients.
snippet: Gmail warns if you have accidentally included a contact with a similar name — instead of the name of the person you usually include in a regular list of e-mail recipients.
lead_paragraph: Like earlier add-ons cooked up by Gmail Labs, a new optional feature for Google’s Web mail service can help save you from yourself. With the experimental “Got the Wrong Bob?” feature turned on, Gmail warns if you have accidentally included a contact with a similar name  instead of the name of the person you usually include in a regular list of e-mail recipients. To activate the feature, log into your Gmail account on the Web, click the green beaker icon to go to the Labs options and click the button to enable “Got the Wrong Bob?” (You can also get there by clicking the Settings link on your Gmail account page and then clicking on the Labs tab.) Click the Save Changes button when finished. A post on the Gmail blog (bit.ly/3VZPIV) has details.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: “Got the Wrong Bob?”

abstract: Revisiting the circumstances surrounding an analyst’s departure from Lehman Brothers.
snippet: Revisiting the circumstances surrounding an analyst’s departure from Lehman Brothers.
lead_paragraph: In August 2008, Lehman Brothers issued a public apology for having plagiarized part of a 60-page report on semiconductor virtualization (whatever that is) from a series of similar reports by Toni Sacconaghi, the first-rate technology analyst at Sanford Bernstein. The Lehman report had been put together by a team of five Lehman analysts who covered the industry. At around the same time the apology was issued, one member of that team, Gordon Johnson, left the firm to go to work for a much smaller institution, Hapoalim Securities. When the Lehman letter came to my attention, I wrote a blog item about it, and, based on a source who was familiar with what had happened — but was not a part of the team that put together the Lehman Brothers report — I wrote that Mr. Johnson had been identified by the firm as the one who had committed the acts of plagiarism and had been fired.

headline.main: Clearing a Name at Lehman

lead_paragraph: The European Union‘s competition commission is busy reviewing Oracle’s acquisition of Sun Microsystems and has said it may not rule until Jan. 19, 2010. abstract: An earlier version of this article referred incorrectly to an assessment of the prospects for legal action in France in connection with a class-action lawsuit against Vivendi in the United States. She did not say that the French shareholders would file a lawsuit in France after the American case was decided.

abstract: No other segment of industry pays out 50 percent of its revenues in bonuses, only Wall Street.
snippet: No other segment of industry pays out 50 percent of its revenues in bonuses, only Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: So yesterday it was the pay czar, Kenneth R. Feinberg, laying down the law for the seven companies that are still wards of the government, including Citigroup, A.I.G., and General Motors. I wrote a special Friday column about that, the essential point of which was that the only way the country is going to get control of executive pay — whether on Wall Street or elsewhere in corporate America — is by making it easier for shareholders to vote out directors who award excessive pay to their company’s chief executive. Ira Kay, the well-known compensation consultant at Watson Wyatt, told me that “board members are terrified” of shareholder votes that would embarrass them.

headline.main: Bailouts and Bonuses

abstract: Microsoft has been making operating system software for cellphones since 1996, but it is losing users to Google’s Android.
snippet: Microsoft has been making operating system software for cellphones since 1996, but it is losing users to Google’s Android.
lead_paragraph: Since 1996, Microsoft has been writing operating systems for little computers to carry in your pocket. It was a lonely business until the company’s perennial rival, Apple, introduced the Web-browsing, music-playing iPhone. But now that smartphones are popular, Microsoft’s operating system, Windows Mobile, is foundering.

headline.main: Big Cellphone Makers Shifting to Android System

abstract: The art owned by financial institutions should get out more — at the least to give the taxpayers, who have been so generous with the financial sector, an aesthetic return.
snippet: The art owned by financial institutions should get out more — at the least to give the taxpayers, who have been so generous with the financial sector, an aesthetic return.
lead_paragraph: Many of the world’s biggest banks  and biggest recipients of government bailouts  have some of the largest collections of art. Some of the works, including abstract pieces and old masters, are hanging in hallways or boardrooms. But much of it is packed away in storage. The art owned by financial institutions should get out more  at the least to give the taxpayers, who have been so generous with the financial sector, an aesthetic return.

headline.main: Banks Hoard Troves of Art

abstract: An article soon to be published in The Journal of Consumer Research explores the self-esteem among women looking at pictures of models.
snippet: An article soon to be published in The Journal of Consumer Research explores the self-esteem among women looking at pictures of models.
lead_paragraph: An article soon to be published in The Journal of Consumer Research explores the self-esteem among women looking at pictures of models. In one experiment, women with low body-mass measurements were shown to have thought about thinness after looking at pictures of skinny models  that is, they hit a responsive key more quickly in response words about thinness than to other words. By contrast, such pictures led heavy women to ponder their contrasts with the models, meaning that they reacted quickest to words related to heaviness.

headline.main: Models Strike a Chord in Self-Esteem
headline.print_headline: Models Strike a Chord in Self-Esteem

lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal said Tuesday that it planned to end a year-and-a-half-old effort to sell its flagship U.S. edition in London. Instead, the newspaper plans to focus its European strategy on a redesigned Wall Street Journal Europe in mid-November.

headline.main: Wall Street Journal Ends Effort to Sell Its U.S. Edition in London

abstract: When policy does not match public opinion on gay and lesbian issues, the policy usually ends up being more conservative than what voters say they want, according to a new academic analysis.
snippet: When policy does not match public opinion on gay and lesbian issues, the policy usually ends up being more conservative than what voters say they want, according to a new academic analysis.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Adam Liptak has a piece in The New York Times today about the disconnect between the public acceptance of gay marriage and its legal adoption. In his article about a California case, public opinion on same-sex marriage (at least in the form of Proposition 8) appears to lag behind the more liberal opinions of the bench.

headline.main: Does Policy Trail Public Opinion on Gay Rights?

abstract: Countries that provide robust incentives for the renewable energy industry represent the safest harbors for investors looking to finance clean energy ventures, according to a new study.
snippet: Countries that provide robust incentives for the renewable energy industry represent the safest harbors for investors looking to finance clean energy ventures, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Countries that adopt policies obliging utilities to purchase a percentage of their power from renewable sources at above-market prices — also known as a “feed-in tariff” — represent the safest harbors for investors looking to finance clean-energy ventures, according to a broad-ranging risk analysis released Monday by Deutsche Bank’s global asset management group and Columbia University’s Earth Institute.

headline.main: Climate Change Policy and Safe Investing
